Fields.DialogueText: Two, if you're going to have vats of highly flammable liquid around, I'd really like the know about it from you directly. Not least because new regulations are...
Oh, calm down, Capitaine - it's just the sort of motivation the crew needs to secure a victory in the upcoming battle.
I've promised all of them a drink once we've won.
No wonder you're so popular.
Oui, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
I have to say, Maillé Brézé - once you were out, there was no stopping you. I was impressed.
I never slow down when I have the advantage, Capitaine. And the crew has been very accommodating with my fighting style as well.

Fields.MenuText: We'll try to work together as best we can.
I think this is the beginning of a great partnership.
We should better communicate our strategy with the crew next time. For their safety.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Capitaine. I appreciate your flexibility.
I concur. Now, let's go congratulate the crew - I owe them all a drink.
I will attempt to do so - but as long as we win, is that really necessary?
Today was the first of many successes. Let's celebrate!
Communication is always necessary, Maillé Brézé.
Hey, Maillé Brézé? There was something I wanted to ask you about before the shooting starts - do you have a minute?
Bien sûr, Capitaine! What's on your mind?
This may sound like an odd question, but - do we *actually* have dozens of casks of liquor on board, off the books?
Non.
Okay. Good.
We have dozens of casks of homemade Curaçao. You wouldn't believe what I went through to get the oranges!
... Okay. One, homemade Curaçao *is* liquor.
But you make it sound so joyless.
Okay, we'd better get to our stations. We'll return to this some other time.
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
You wanted to see me, Capitaine?
Yes, Maillé Brézé. First of all, congratulations on another victory.
Thank you, Capitaine. I bring my best to every battle.
I was wondering if my orders to momentarily delay firing reached you?
... They did.
Then why did you fire?
Our enemy was within range and I wanted to avoid enduring additional damage, Capitaine. You might not be a ship, but I am.
You should have stood by as I had asked. The crew was not prepared for you to fire the guns. Luckily, no one was hurt, but some still haven't regained their hearing.
They'll recover, in time. And we completed our mission.

Fields.MenuText: We did, and thank you again. But be more considerate of others.
I suppose. Your dauntlessness is admirable.
Still, I need you to follow my orders. Future battles might not go our way if you don't.

Fields.DialogueText: We can only be considerate for so many and win the battle.
I'm a part of the Marine Nationale. Bravery is normal.
I listen to my instincts under times of stress. Those instincts have never led me astray.
... Very well. Go and celebrate today's victory. I'll join you shortly.
Merci, Capitaine.
Be on the lookout for the Morganas. I've received reports that they're swarming this area.
Will we be fighting them all, Capitaine?
The ones that we run into, yes. I'm hopeful that won't be all of them.
Hopefully not.
Listen, you *do* remember the conversation we had the other day, right?
Not particularly - I apologize. Could you refresh my memory?
Communication? Consideration? Does that sound familiar?
Captain! We have Morganas approaching on the starboard side!
Get to your station, Maillé Brézé.
Bien sûr!
@BATTLE
I apologize, Capitaine. I wasn't aware Officer Bernard...
Maillé Brézé, what did I say just before the battle? Communication? Consideration? Do you remember those words?
Oui.
Then why was Lieutenant Bernard injured? As I understand it, you assumed control of the 138 mm gun he was operating and wrenched it violently enough to throw him to the ground and fracture his elbow.
I was invested in the battle, Capitaine. And I had a very urgent target for that gun.

Fields.MenuText: Well now, I'll be the one to write to Bernard's family letting them know he's been injured.
Invested or not, it was reckless and unbecoming of you.
Take time to think about what you've done.

Fields.DialogueText: There would have been far more injuries had I not acted.
I'll decide what's becoming of me. I saved us from more injuries.
I acted in the best interest of the crew at large.
... Fine.
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Was my performance more to your liking today, Capitaine?
I suppose. You're a smart fighter, so there wasn't much to worry about on that front.
Merci. I appreciate that, Capitaine.
That said, we'll discuss safety protocols later on, when I can better understand your fighting strategies. Do you have anything else to report?
I brewed more of the Curaçao and was wondering if you'd join me and the crew.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry - no can do. I'll be overseeing the lookouts soon.
Thanks, but go on without me - I'll catch up as soon as I can. I'm drafting new protocols right now.
Absolutely - thank you. But we do need to discuss precautionary steps soon.

Fields.DialogueText: Why are you taking it upon yourself to inherit Lieutenant Bernard's duties?
I hardly think that's something that needs your immediate attention.
Soon? We've discussed safety multiple times in the past. Aren't you getting sick of it?
Madame Maîtresse du Dunkerque, safety and cautionary steps are important to the Marine Nationale - and to me. Please just accept it and move on. Okay?
But I...
We'll talk later. For now, you're dismissed.
Oui, Capitaine.
Bonjour, Capitaine. You wanted to see me?
I did. It's past time we work out a viable set of safety protocols.
Will I have any voice in what we implement?
That's why you're here.
What did you have in mind, specifically?

Fields.MenuText: Simple things, mostly. Notify relevant personnel before you go on the offensive - particularly in you're assuming control of their stations.
Follow my orders, regardless of instinct. Always.
Let's start with the obvious - always check in with me before you start firing on the enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: I was absorbed in the battle last time, but I will try my best in the future.
That will be easier said than done, but I will do my best to follow your directives.
I will struggle at first, but I'll try.
I appreciate that. And, listen, I know you have superb combat instincts - I just need you to respect your crew when under pressure. Does that make sense to you?
Of course - Capitaine, there are Morganas headed this direction, from the south.
Then let's head out. Prepare for battle!
Oui, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
But this is another injury that's directly attributable to your recklessness. You know that, right?
I was trying to head off a Morgana barrage! I wasn't trying to do anything rash.
But you didn't follow my orders. Listen. after we deal with this incoming Morgana, we'll get into this in depth.
Well, I'm certainly not looking forward to it!
@BATTLE
Maillé Brézé, this is Lieutenant Moreau. I gather you haven't had a chance to speak, but I'm sure you've seen him around.
Bonjour, Madame. We did share a drink once, at the very least.
Bonjour! It's a pleasure. But... why did you summon him, Capitaine?
Reports of our recent difficulties have found their way back to Command, and it has been strongly suggested that I bring in a mediator.
I'm honored by your request, Capitaine.
Yes, you're so... honorable, Capitaine. Do you feel like a mediator is necessary for us to communicate?

Fields.MenuText: Not really. No offense, Lieutenant. But this way we can say we tried.
An outside point of view could be useful. It's worth a shot, at least.
Lt. Moreau is assigned this task whether you like it or not.

Fields.DialogueText: I see your point. Lt. Moreau, what did you have in mind for us?
Don't you feel we should be able to handle our differences ourselves?
Fine. What, then?
I must draft my next report for you, Capitaine, but within the week I would like to have a discussion of what the two of you have been experiencing.
You mean we can't settle this right now?
I defer to the Lieutenant. And you and I both have other duties to attend to.
Thank you, Capitaine.
Very well.
Well, this forestalls getting the admirals any further involved, which I think is a high priority for both of us. I think we should at least give it a try.
Eh, bien.
You'll be relieved to know that Dubois is going to survive.
Dieu merci!
If you agree, I propose we ask the Lieutenant here to serve. It's less intrusive than bringing in an outsider, and I trust his judgment.
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
The ship's most recent battles have been too... animated. Dubois had a heart attack and had to be discharged.
Capitaine, with all due respect, Dubois might have honestly feared I was pushing the boilers past their safety limits, but I'm in a position to know better.
A decent point.

Fields.MenuText: But you didn't give the man so much as a hint of what was happening. He had every reason to believe the engine room was simply going to explode.
That "probablement" is telling. We don't know what would have happened if you'd followed orders.
It's not, though. I'm not going to concede the point that unless my ship disobeys instructions we're all going to die.

Fields.DialogueText: As though I would ever let that happen! I'll have you know, the crew has more faith in me than you do!
Exactly. We'll never know. All we can know is that I did what I did and we didn't sink. I'm sorry that's not good enough for you!
Even if it's true? What do I have to do to please you - stand still while the enemy blows holes in me?!
Now, Maîtresse...
Je suis désolée, but I don't want to listen to either of you right now. You both owe me your lives many times over. You should thank me for my actions, not reprimand me.
Thank you for your actions. Now, do better next time! All you need is to...
It was just one sailor! He didn't even die!
And, for the record, I count *two* sailors who sufferend injuries that could've been avoided with a bit of care. Dubois and Bernard.
I've had enough of this conversation.
... That could have gone better.
You don't say.
And my maneuvers saved lives. Probablement.
"He didn't even die?" Really? That's your response?
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine.
Bonjour to you, too. It's been a while.
Well, I haven't been in the mood to speak to you.
But you are now?
That the victory justified the recklessness? That I'm just grateful there aren't more members of my crew in the infirmary?
Exactly that, Capitaine. Can't you see how my quick actions prevented further injuries? How I kept us afloat?

Fields.MenuText: That's all true. But sailors are still getting hurt because the ship randomly comes alive and tosses them around. The one doesn't cancel out the other.
Can't *you* see there's room for improvement?
Look, I'm not trying to make you miserable here. I'm not picking on you for the fun of it!

Fields.DialogueText: Non, you're wrong! It does!
That's not what you're saying. You're saying you'd be happier with a ship without a woken Belle.
Capitaine, you can't tie my hands just because you're afraid. Ce n'est pas juste.
... I think we need to take a break before this escalates.
As you wish, Capitaine.
I thought you might have something to say to me after our last battle.
You're making mistakes. I honestly think the crew will forgive you just about anything, but the powers that be back in Paris won't.
If we can't sort this out ourselves, things will get a lot more complicated.
Plus, more important, I'm really afraid someone will die in a way I should have found a way to prevent.
You wanted to see me, Captain?
Yes, meet me in my quarters once the battle's over. I have things to discuss.
Of course.
@BATTLE
Lt. Moreau, I'd like to discuss forthcoming safety procedures.
Don't you think Maillé Brézé should be included in this conversation?
I've tried. Repeatedly. At this point, I'm obliged to at least consider implementing protocols that aren't contingent on her willing participation.
But...
Capitaine, you of all people should know that I am the manifestation of this ship. I know all and see all that goes on within and around me.

Fields.MenuText: Then tell me, how do you so frequently fail to take your crew members' positions into account?
Oh, hi. Does this mean I've finally gotten your attention?
And, what? Now you want to be a part of this conversation?

Fields.DialogueText: Tread carefully, Capitaine.
You ignore me far more often than I ignore you, Capitaine.
I certainly don't want to be ignored.
Tell me I'm wrong, then! Tell me that bringing you in to talk about crew safety would result in something - anything! - other than you saying I should be grateful and then storming out!
And your solution is to abuse my trust? My respect for you?
Lt. Moreau, I'm sorry...
Apologies are not necessary, Capitaine. I was a therapist in civilian life, and I've certainly seen worse.
But, listen, my sense is that she very much desires your respect. Criticism, however well intentioned, stimulates an... exaggerated response.
Not right this minute, obviously.
You're constantly defensive, and it's getting in the way of us doing our jobs. It has to stop!
I can't claim to be an expert on supernatural psychology, but - you might want to consider applying some encouragement. Build a rapport.
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
What is it, Capitaine?
I wanted to congratulate you on another victory.
Is that all?

Fields.MenuText: Maillé Brézé, I am sorry for offending you.
I don't know where to start.
I can congratulate you in greater depth, if you like.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure.
Should I give you time to order your thoughts?
Save your breath, Capitaine.
Maillé Brézé, I...
I struggle with people who have authority over me. Rarely have I encountered an authority figure who I thought had my best interests at heart.
So far... you haven't seemed all that different from all the others.
Nothing to say, Capitaine? Then I'll take my leave.
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Oui, Capitaine?
I just wanted to thank you. Salute you, really. Over the last few battles, I've had no reports of crew confusion, and no injuries that weren't the result of enemy action or plain bad luck.
I... appreciate your praise, Capitaine. But there's no need to keep calling me in.
I always used to after a successful battle.
Maybe a few times in the beginning. But now you've done so every time since your meeting with Lt. Moreau.

Fields.MenuText: About that...
You don't appreciate encouragement?
Maybe I would like to get to know you better, so we can begin cooperating again.

Fields.DialogueText: Please, Capitaine. These frequent meetings have not helped at all.
Not forced encouragement, no.
I am the Maillé Brézé. We're already cooperating, to some degree.
Listen, whatever our differences, you should know that nothing I've said has been insincere. Or inaccurate.
Do you mean, ''When will you forget that I arranged a meeting behind your back?''
No, that's not what I meant.
Is there anything else you have to say to me? Because otherwise, I have places I'd rather be.
I've seen you celebrating with the crew after battles.
I choose to spend time with the people who place faith in me. Is something wrong? Maybe you feel excluded?
No. But I have noticed that only half the crew attends your celebrations anymore.
... Please don't call me in again if I do not need to be here.
A fractured crew isn't good for anyone. Not for you. Not for me. Not for them.
... They'll come around eventually.
Just like you'll come around to me eventually?
... Until the next battle, Capitaine.
Very well.
You've been doing outstanding work.
But has it been respectful? Has it really felt earned to you?
Maillé Brézé, what is it going to take to get this chip off your shoulder?
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Maillé Brézé.
Maillé Brézé, I request your presence.
Men were injured this time, so I don't think you're calling to congratulate me.
What happened back there?
I thought I knew best.
But you don't. Not always. I am the commander of this vessel, and...
My instincts to fight used to be so accurate. It isn't my intention to put anyone in harm's way.

Fields.MenuText: Your instincts should mean nothing when I give direct orders.
You had me believing that you were able to work with the crew.
I know. But it happens.

Fields.DialogueText: Humph.
I was, up until you put me in a risky position.
Okay. Seventeen men were wounded because their equipment didn't act the way they expected it to or because you maneuvered without warning. How do you think we should handle this situation?
We go about our business and keep fighting.
No. Maillé Brézé, I like you. I even admire you. But you need to stop acting like the crew are just accessories during battle.
I'm not! I have everyone's best interests at heart. If I survive, then so will everyone else.
That's not a guarantee, Maillé Brézé. Three of those injured men were severely hurt. The doctors aren't sure whether they'll recover.
I'm sure that they will. And then we can all get on with our work.
Maillé Brézé. Listen to yourself.
Am I dismissed?
... Yes. Go on your way.
I suppose you've heard the grumblings, Maillé Brézé.
About me, Capitaine?
Yes. I've been getting complaints from some of the crew.
I've heard them but I haven't paid much attention. What's happening?
They feel as if you don't care for them. They feel as if they're pawns in your scheme.
In my scheme? How can that be? They don't serve me.

Fields.MenuText: You never take the time to brief them on what you're planning. Or warn them when you act.
We all serve one another, in our own ways.
Don't they?

Fields.DialogueText: There's not enough time to do so in the midst of battle. Besides, they're your men. You should be the one communicating with them.
I'm not sure what on earth you mean by that.
No. They serve you, not me.
You may not trust me, but pay more attention to how the crew acts around you. When we win, see how they celebrate a victory with you. Just try it.
Now, prepare for battle.
Oui, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
You were right, Capitaine.
Excuse me?
About the crew and their opinions toward me. I listened to their conversations about me. I felt how they reloaded the guns.
What was different?
It was slower and unenthusiastic. I offered some of the Curaçao after we had won, but... nobody seemed in the mood to celebrate.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think we should do?
You deserve to know what people think about you.
I told you your actions would eventually catch up to you.

Fields.DialogueText: Je ne sais pas. It's... I just don't know.
It doesn't bring me joy to know. But living in a false reality is even worse.
Je suppose. Perhaps I do need to reevaluate some things.
Let's focus on the future. Have you thought about...
Je suis désolée d'interrompre - but it'll have to wait. I'm sensing Morganas approaching.
Yeah, they have a way of doing that. Let's go.
@BATTLE
Lt. Moreau, may I have a word with you?
Right now? A battle is upon us!
I know. But meet me back here when the shooting's done.
I... yeah, okay!
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine. Madame. May I ask why I was summoned?
We believe it's time to find a strategy to work together better.
Why now?

Fields.MenuText: Maillé Brézé felt a change was necessary when the crew began questioning her commitment to them.
Maybe tempers have just had time to cool.
Why not?

Fields.DialogueText: I will admit as much.
They have. And I would like to be more considerate of the crew.
Please guide us, Lt. Moreau.
Well, I'll do my best for you both.
I appreciate that. Any suggestions would be welcome.
I think it would be helpful for you two to get to know one another.
Excuse me?
As the Belle and captain of this vessel, it's important that you know each other well.
... Why?
Because you're going to be working together, day in and day out, in and out of battle, for the foreseeable future. And in order to trust one another, you have to know one another.
... You truly believe that would help us?
It's the best solution I have right now, after observing you both.
Well. Shall we grab a drink later, Maillé Brézé?
Um, all right, Capitaine... let's.
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Excellent battle today, Maillé Brézé.
I know you think you have to keep saying that...
I said it because it's true. You have excellent instincts, and you worked with the crew just about flawlessly.
Okay.

Fields.MenuText: Is something wrong?
Did I say something that offended you?
Are you hiding something?

Fields.DialogueText: Rien de mal. Lt. Moreau's suggestions just made me nervous.
Non. I'm just a little agitated is all, Capitaine.
Non. I'm not. I'm just not accustomed to this.
I don't need to know your life forward and backward. I just want to know you well enough that we can work together better.
All right.
Do you...
Désolée, Capitaine, but I'm not comfortable doing this right now. This is just... going to take some time. I will continue this with you later.
I have five sisters.
Excuse me?
My family consists of my five sisters and me.  And approximately 200 crewmen that I want to make more of an effort to protect.
*ALARM*
I'd like to hear more about them. Later?
@BATTLE
You're a master of Romantic languages, you can navigate without a compass, and yet you still rely on pure reflex to get you through a battle?
Mais... vous avez raison. A lot of it is reflex rather than strategy. And it hasn't been the source of any problems... until recently.
In fairness, at least some of the problem is just that we haven't found a good way to train the crew to anticipate the reactions of a conscious destroyer. And I am working on that.
I appreciate that, Capitaine.
Do you mind if I ask what prompted you to talk about all this?
The Curaçao helped me quite a bit.
I think the crew finds it helpful as well.
J'admets... I've enjoyed this time we have together, Capitaine. It is... helping me learn what you think is important.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean by that?
Doing our part for the world is what's most important.
Destroying the Morganas should be the biggest priority, if you ask me.

Fields.DialogueText: When I know what you value most, I can act accordingly in battle.
What I really want to know is what's important for you.
I concur, but I really want to know the root of that mindset.
I suppose it would be helpful for me to understand what you value most as well.
Think you're up to the task of figuring it out?
Given enough time, I think so.
Perhaps we'll come to understand one another yet.
Stranger things have happened.
D'accord.
Don't get me wrong - I'm grateful when the ship just seems to lunge out of the path of a dozen falling bombs.
You can understand why I take that kind of thing personally.
Not that I'm encouraging recklessness on your part, but... well, I do like it when you keep us all from dying.
Morganas are inbound!
Evasive maneuvers! Maillé Brézé, I want you to head west. If we can rendezvous with Captain Keita's group we'll have another battleship to bring to bear - and I like those odds.
If we take a stand here, we risk damaged Morganas breaking from combat and heading right for La Rochelle. Besides, you can dodge `em as we go - I've seen you work.
Capitaine... non. I need you to trust me on this.
Maillé Brézé, no!
@BATTLE
That was nearly a disaster for the fleet, Maillé Brézé.
You failed to mention that we did succeed in defeating the Morganas. Because of my quick actions.

Fields.MenuText: What do you want me to say? "Insubordination is what this fleet needs?"
Everything we've been working toward recently - you just threw it out the window!
Thank you for completing our objective. Only one of our objectives.

Fields.DialogueText: Listen to yourself! All you care about is me blindly following your orders!
Oh, should I apologize for wanting to avoid sustaining damage?
The Morganas are gone and the men are out of harm's way.
No. That's it. The crew is *endangered* when guns go off on their own. The crew is *endangered* when officers can't predict which way the ship is going to go. If you can't get that into your head...
Capitaine...
I was in danger. I didn't want to sink. Did you think of that?
You both need to stop! Think about what you've both done and discuss this later!
Capitaine... with all due respect, I don't want to be taking fire for hours while we try to find reinforcements!
We have the advantage now - if we take a stand...
Did you really think I was going to let that happen?! That the *crew* was going to let that happen?
Seriously, what do you think we all are? Just parasites?
Non! But that doesn't mean I should just sit back and wait to get shot because somebody's plan says it's practical!
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Capitaine?
Yes? What is it?
Was my performance satisfactory today?
It was adequate. Have you checked in on the injured from our last battle?
I tried... they didn't want to see me.
Any idea how many we'll need to find replacements for?
Hopefully you won't have to find any.

Fields.MenuText: Eventually, I will.
When I thought we were understanding each other, I had hoped that would be the case.
You've broken my trust, Maillé Brézé.

Fields.DialogueText: You don't know that, Capitaine. If you'd do a better job of protecting me, maybe everyone would be safer.
I care for my own safety too, Capitaine.
Does this mean you no longer care for my safety?
You know, I've figured out what you value most.
Oh, have you now?
I have.
Well, this ought to be rich.
What means the most to you... is you.
Don't you say that. You know I love the crew.
You love the crew, right up until your own life is in danger. And then it's as if some switch is pressed in your head and self-preservation becomes your only focus.
In case you hadn't noticed, I am the ship. If I go down, it's abandon ship for everyone on board. Do you really expect me to sacrifice myself?
In a matter of speaking, yes.
... Excuse me?
We're the leaders of this crew, Maillé Brézé. And as the leaders, we have more of a responsibility than anyone else on board to lay down our lives for the crew.
Now, if we're both doing our jobs, that won't happen. As captain, it's my responsibility to keep you and the crew safe. And as the ship, it's your responsibility to keep me and the crew safe.
Looking out for one another makes us strong. But prioritizing self-preservation... that tears us apart.
We both need to be willing to put others first. The crew needs to know that you're capable of valuing their lives above your own.
Lieutenant Bernard made such a sacrifice for us all.
Bernard? Did he...?
He died of injuries sustained in the last battle. I received word just before you arrived.
Morganas approaching... and the way they're armored... I haven't seen anything like this...
Tell the men to prepare for battle. And... tell them to work harder for Maillé Brézé. We'll need everyone working together if we're going to defeat this horde.
Right away, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
Maillé Brézé, can I see you?
Oui?
I wanted to commend you for your work today. You're always excellent in the field.
What do you really have to say to me, Capitaine?
If you would like to request a different captain from Command, I'll prepare the paperwork for you. I want you under leadership that will be beneficial to you, that will allow you to grow.
I'm not sure whether I'm the right captain for the job.
... Non.

Fields.MenuText: After all that's happened, you still want to work together?
I don't think we'll be able to continue.
Why do you say that?

Fields.DialogueText: ... We've been through so much. We can't give up, Capitaine.
I think we can... if we try to persevere.
We may have... several differences, but I can see your value as a captain.
We should visit Lt. Moreau.
If you say so.
Well... here we are... again...
How are the two of you doing?
The capitaine said... some things... which made me reevaluate my role aboard this ship. And how I conduct myself during times of... stress.
I see.
Since I've been awake, I've lived my life with two things in mind. One, it's my mission to defeat every Morgana I see. Two, I have to look out for my own well-being... because no one else will.
However, the Capitaine helped me realize that this way of living, this lack of trust... well, it's detrimental to the crew. Who I do care for.
And I've realized that, in spite of our differences, the Capitaine really is invested in my best interests. I think.
I am.
D'accord. Like I said.
It's just going to... take some time... maybe a lot more time... for me to really wrap my head around all this.
And... why did you need to tell me all this?
I wasn't sure I would be able to say it to the Capitaine's face, you know, if it was just the two of us. I thought it would be easier to say it to you, and to have the Capitaine overhear.
Heh.
Well, as unorthodox as your methods might be, Maillé Brézé, I think this is good progress on your part. Let me know if I can be of any further service to you both.
Thank you, Moreau.
*ALARM*
Ready?
Ready.
Maybe not all the time, and not from any malice, but in the heat of battle, people... well, I've been hurt when I didn't think I had to be. You see?
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
It's happening again, Capitaine.
What's wrong?
The crew... they're... hesitant to be cooperative.

Fields.MenuText: They do their jobs when the shooting starts. We're not looking at mutiny.
Yeah. I'm still receiving complaints.
We just have to work through it.

Fields.DialogueText: Still. I don't know what I'm supposed to do to fix this.
I tried apologizing for my actions, but to no avail.
... What should we do?
Be patient. I'll continue to observe them in the coming days. We'll work this out.
How?
Through time and effort. Show them that you're willing to protect them. They'll take notice.
It hasn't been easy, Moreau, convincing the crew to trust that the guns aren't going to start spinning around on them when the Morganas come.
But she's trying her best to put their needs above hers. I know it must be hard, but she's doing it.
I think the crew has noticed the changes she's made. I'm hearing less grumbling than I used to.
That's good to know. The sooner I can get us acting like a unit, the safer we'll be when fighting whatever Morganas come our way.
So... how is the crew doing? That is what the two of you were discussing, wasn't it?

Fields.MenuText: We weren't trying to hide this conversation from you - honest!
We can't keep anything from you. Moreau thinks he sees some progress.
Good news or bad news first?

Fields.DialogueText: I know, don't worry. I... trust you.
If that were so, that would be a relief.
Do I have to pick?
*ALARM*
It's that time.
Time to see how the crew and I do this time around.
@BATTLE
That was...
Yes?
An improvement, don't you think?
I think so. I still sensed some hesitation on the crew's part, but... no more dread.
No more dread is definitely an improvement.
Heh. Merci, Capitaine.
No. There's been some progress, but it's still a long road yet.
That's fair, I suppose.
Come on, men! Battle stations! We're not going to taste the Curaçao if we're underwater!
Prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
I... I don't know what to say.
What do you mean?

Fields.MenuText: You warned everyone before you fired.
Not once did a crew member roll his eyes when he had to reload the guns.
All the officers were made aware of what your next move would be.

Fields.DialogueText: I felt more energized today. And I didn't want anyone to get hurt.
The promise of liqueur probably helped.
Taking time to communicate slowed us down a little... but I think we were more efficient.
This is excellent progress, Maillé Brézé. I'm proud of you.
That... that means a lot, Capitaine.
Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Another battle won, and our sailors are happy and safe.
I can only do my best, and hope everyone aboard does as well.
La Maîtressee du Dunkerque, I have difficulty imagining a Belle more... interesting than you.
Do you mean that as a compliment?
I do. Our time together hasn't been the easiest... but it takes a remarkable character to persist through this much difficulty.
So, I'm interesting and remarkable. I'll take both those compliments, thank you.

Fields.MenuText: As you should. I hope our friendship lasts a lifetime.
In fact, you're... well, you're somewhat special to me.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, I don't think I'll ever find another captain quite like you.
What a curious thing to say.
It's just... this war is taking a huge toll on the world.
We can only hope to make the best of our situation.
You're right. And we have, haven't we?
I was just about to say the same thing.
Should we retire to the mess hall? Celebrate with the crew?
I did see an officer with a bottle of 1920 Chateau Lafite Rothschild...
Wine? Are you really prepared to settle?
Ne craignez rien. The company will make up for the low alcohol content, Capitaine.
That's what I thought.
Shall we?
I think I was wrong earlier. This is the beginning of a great partnership.
